Award.AwardTitle: NSF National Robotics Initiative (NRI) 2016 PI Meeting

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: The objective of this award is to organize the annual Principal Investigators (PI) meeting for the National Robotics Initiative (NRI), which was launched in 2011. The PI meeting brings together the community of researchers, companies, and program officers who are actively engaged in the NRI to provide cross-project coordination in terms of common intellectual challenges, methods for education and training, best practices in terms of transition of results, and a centralized and lasting repository illustrating the research ideas explored and milestones achieved by the NRI projects. The meeting will be two days during late fall 2016 in the vicinity of Washington DC. The format will include short presentations by all the attending PIs, a poster session, keynote speeches, and panel discussions. Invitations to the meeting will include all PIs with active NRI grants, program managers with robotics-related programs, and members of the press.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2016 NRI PI meeting was held on November 29th and 30th, 2016. The event brought together the community of researchers, companies,  program managers, interested government agencies who are  engaged in or funded by the NRI program. They shared results, discussed findings, and learned about the topics and concerns in robotics research, commercialization, education,  outreach and the future of the NRI program. The agenda included plenary sessions on emerging trends in robotics research, the start-up culture and industry keynotes. 

 

The meeting was attended by 341 people. Advance registration included 305 participants, with a  number of people registering on site. 

 

The National Robotics Initiative has a goal to accelerate the development  of robots that work with people. This includes co-robots working in symbiotic relationships with humans. The initiative has the support of many federal agencies including the National Science Foundation (NSF), the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), and the U.S. Department of Defense (DOD). The aims and applications are extremely diverse covering areas from agriculture, medicine, artificial intelligence, cognitive science and mechanical engineering. The interaction of these diverse disciplines serves to build a stronger research community base and solve the cross-cutting demands to fulfill the NRI goal.  Consequently, leveraging the annual PI meeting to facilitate the dissemination of results across fields will also further the NRI goals.

 

This year’s PI meeting featured four poster sessions with 348 posters presented. Some of these posters are available online on the meeting’s web site (https://nri2016.seas.upenn.edu/poster-uploads/).   In addition, four government agencies (USDA, NASA, NIH and DOE) took advantage of the convergence of PIs to hold separate strategic meetings for their participants. Respective government agency representatives also each had a four minute presentation at the beginning of a rapid session to introduce their agency's research focus and funding opportunities.
